pages.description: Complete API reference for Chiron documentation builder
pages.content: API Reference This page documents the Chiron builder API and configuration options. Table of Contents Configuration File Project Configuration Branding Configuration Build Commands Template Variables Configuration File The chiron.config.yaml file is the heart of your documentation site. Project Configuration project: name: string # Project name title: string # Page title (for <title> tag) description: string # Project description language: string # Language code (e.g., 'en', 'it') base_url: string # Full base URL of your site Branding Configuration branding: company: string # Company/organization name company_url: string # Company website URL tagline: string # Project tagline logo: light: string # Logo for light theme dark: string # Logo for dark theme alt: string # Alt text for logo footer_light: string footer_dark: string Navigation Configuration navigation: header: - label: string url: string sidebar: - section: string # Section title items: - label: string file: string # Markdown file (e.g., 'page.md') # OR url: string # External URL external: boolean breadcrumb: enabled: boolean items: - label: string url: string external: boolean SEO Configuration seo: keywords: - string opengraph: site_name: string type: string locale: string image: string image_width: number image_height: number image_alt: string twitter: card: string site: string creator: string Features Toggle features: search: boolean code_copy: boolean table_of_contents: boolean breadcrumbs: boolean cookie_consent: boolean dark_mode: boolean print_styles: boolean scroll_to_top: boolean syntax_highlighting: boolean Build Configuration build: output_dir: string # Output directory (default: 'docs') content_dir: string # Content directory (default: 'content') assets_dir: string # Assets directory (default: 'assets') templates_dir: string # Templates directory (default: 'templates') static_files: - string # Files to copy (supports * wildcard) sitemap: enabled: boolean priority: number # Default priority (0.0-1.0) changefreq: string # always|hourly|daily|weekly|monthly|yearly|never robots: enabled: boolean allow_all: boolean Markdown Frontmatter Each Markdown file can include YAML frontmatter: --- title: Page Title description: Page description author: Author Name date: 2025 - 01 - 01 custom_field: Custom value --- # Content starts here Supported Frontmatter Fields Field Type Description title string Page title (overrides config) description string Page description for SEO author string Page author date string Publication date CLI Commands Build Build the documentation site: npm run build Watch Mode Build and watch for changes: npm run dev Preview Preview the built site: npm run preview Clean Remove the output directory: npm run clean Programmatic API You can also use Chiron programmatically: const ChironBuilder = require ( './builder' ); const builder = new ChironBuilder ( 'chiron.config.yaml' ); // Build once await builder. build (); // Watch mode builder. watch (); Template Variables When creating custom templates, these variables are available: Page Variables {{PAGE_TITLE}} - Page title {{PAGE_LANG}} - Page language {{PAGE_CONTENT}} - Rendered page content Project Variables {{PROJECT_NAME}} - Project name {{PROJECT_DESCRIPTION}} - Project description {{COMPANY_NAME}} - Company name {{COMPANY_URL}} - Company URL GitHub Variables {{GITHUB_OWNER}} - GitHub repository owner {{GITHUB_REPO}} - GitHub repository name {{GITHUB_URL}} - Full GitHub repository URL Navigation Variables {{NAVIGATION}} - Rendered sidebar navigation {{BREADCRUMB}} - Rendered breadcrumb Meta Variables {{META_TAGS}} - All meta tags (SEO, OG, Twitter) {{STRUCTURED_DATA}} - JSON-LD structured data Markdown Extensions Chiron supports GitHub Flavored Markdown with these extensions: Code Blocks with Copy Button // Code blocks automatically get a copy button function example () { return 'Hello, World!' ; } Tables Tables are automatically wrapped in a responsive container: Column 1 Column 2 Column 3 Data 1 Data 2 Data 3 External Links External links automatically get target="_blank" and rel="noopener" : External Link Syntax Highlighting Supported languages: JavaScript/TypeScript Python CSS/SCSS Bash/Shell JSON/YAML Markdown And many more via Prism.js Examples Minimal Configuration project: name: My Docs title: My Documentation base_url: https: //example.github.io/docs navigation: sidebar: - section: Docs items: - label: Home file: index.md Full Configuration See chiron.config.yaml in the repository root for a complete example with all available options. Troubleshooting Build Errors If you encounter build errors: Check your YAML syntax in chiron.config.yaml Ensure all referenced Markdown files exist in content/ Verify file paths are correct (relative to project root) Missing Pages If pages don't appear: Check the file is in the content/ directory Verify it'

pages.title: Dashboard Demo
pages.description: Example page using a custom dashboard sidebar with widgets
pages.content: Dashboard Demo This page demonstrates the custom sidebar template feature. Instead of showing standard navigation links, the sidebar displays a dashboard-style interface with widgets. Custom Sidebar Features The sidebar on this page is completely custom and includes: üìä Stats Widget Displays key metrics and statistics pulled from the sidebar configuration. üîó Quick Links Widget Curated links to important pages, both internal and external. ‚ÑπÔ∏è Custom HTML Widget Arbitrary HTML content for announcements, status indicators, or marketing messages. üì¶ Project Info Widget Dynamic information from the main Chiron configuration. How It Works The custom sidebar is defined in sidebars.yaml : dashboard: template: custom-templates/dashboard-sidebar.ejs title: "Dashboard Stats" stats: Pages: "23" Tests: "730+" Uptime: "99.9%" Version: "0.7.0" quickLinks: - label: GitHub Repository url: https: //github.com/agilira/chiron external: true customHtml: "<div>...</div>" The template file ( custom-templates/dashboard-sidebar.ejs ) receives all this configuration data and can render any HTML/CSS you need. Security Features All custom templates have access to security utilities: escapeHtml(str) - Prevents XSS attacks by escaping HTML entities sanitizeUrl(url) - Validates and sanitizes URLs to prevent javascript: injections Use Cases Custom sidebars are perfect for: Admin Dashboards - Show system stats, quick actions, notifications Marketing Pages - Display CTAs, testimonials, feature highlights E-commerce Sites - Product filters, categories, shopping cart widget Project Documentation - Build status, test coverage, deployment info Support Portals - Contact info, search box, popular articles Template Priority System Chiron uses a WordPress-style template priority: Config-level template - Specified in sidebars.yaml (highest priority) Theme-level partial - themes/THEME/templates/partials/sidebar.ejs Built-in default - Standard navigation rendering (fallback) This allows themes to customize the sidebar appearance while individual sidebars can override with completely custom templates. Mobile Compatibility The custom sidebar works seamlessly with Chiron's responsive design. On mobile devices (<1024px), the sidebar becomes a slide-out menu accessible via the hamburger icon. Try it yourself! Check the sidebar on this page to see the dashboard widgets in action.

pages.title: Data Island Pattern - Complete Guide
pages.description: Comprehensive documentation for the Data Island Pattern in Chiron
pages.content: üèùÔ∏è Data Island Pattern - Complete Guide Il Data Island Pattern √® una tecnica per iniettare dati a build-time direttamente nell'HTML, eliminando la necessit√† di chiamate HTTP a runtime. üéØ Quando Usarlo ‚úÖ Use Cases Perfetti Widgets Interattivi Related Posts Widget - Lista articoli correlati (zero fetch, SEO-friendly) Recent Articles - Ultimi articoli con sorting/filtering client-side Author Bio Cards - Info autore con social links interattivi Product Listings - Catalogo prodotti con filtri e ricerca Comment Counters - Visualizzazione conteggi senza API Componenti Dinamici Search Widgets - Indice di ricerca pre-generato Analytics Dashboards - Metriche pre-calcolate dal build Interactive Maps - Coordinate e markers gi√† nell'HTML Chart Components - Dati per grafici disponibili immediatamente Filter Panels - Opzioni di filtro pre-caricate Progressive Enhancement User Preferences UI - Settings con valori default Form Wizards - Dati di configurazione step-by-step Validation Rules - Regole di validazione complesse Localization Data - Traduzioni per UI dinamiche üìñ Come Funziona Step 1: Aggiungi Dati al Frontmatter --- title: My Blog Post description: An awesome post author: John Doe tags: [react, performance, seo] relatedPosts: - title: First Related url: /posts/first - title: Second Related url: /posts/second customConfig: apiEndpoint: https: //api.example.com maxItems: 10 theme: dark --- Step 2: Usa il Shortcode con `data` Attribute <App id= "related-posts-widget" framework= "vanilla" src= "/assets/widgets/related-posts.js" data= "page.title,page.tags,page.relatedPosts" > <div class = "placeholder" >Loading related posts...</div> </App> Step 3: Chiron Genera il Data Island Durante il build, Chiron genera: <!-- Data Island - injected at build time --> <script type= "application/json" id= "related-posts-widget-data" > { "title" : "My Blog Post" , "tags" : [ "react" , "performance" , "seo" ], "relatedPosts" : [ { "title" : "First Related" , "url" : "/posts/first" }, { "title" : "Second Related" , "url" : "/posts/second" } ] } </script> <!-- Lazy-loaded container --> <div class = "lazy-app-container" data-lazy-app= "vanilla" data-script-src= "/assets/widgets/related-posts.js" id= "related-posts-widget" > <div class = "placeholder" >Loading related posts...</div> </div> Step 4: L'App Legge i Dati // assets/widgets/related-posts.js ( function () { 'use strict' ; document. addEventListener ( 'lazy-app-loaded' , function (event) { if (event.detail.appId !== 'related-posts-widget' ) return ; const container = event.detail.container; // Read injected Data Island const dataScript = document. getElementById ( 'related-posts-widget-data' ); const data = JSON. parse (dataScript.textContent); // Render with zero HTTP requests! const html = ` <div class="related-posts"> <h3>Related to: ${data.title}</h3> <ul> ${data.relatedPosts.map(post => ` <li><a href= "${post.url}" >${post.title}</a></li> `).join('')} </ul> <div class="tags"> ${data.tags.map(tag => ` <span class = "tag" >${tag}</span> `).join('')} </div> </div> ` ; container.innerHTML = html; }); })(); üìä Cosa Puoi Iniettare? Il Data Island pu√≤ accedere a tutto il context disponibile durante il rendering della pagina. üîπ Dati Pagina Corrente # Nel frontmatter title: My Page description: Page description author: John Doe date: 2024 - 01 - 15 tags: [tag1, tag2] category: tutorials # Dati custom arbitrari myCustomData: apiKey: abc123 settings: theme: dark lang: it Accesso nel shortcode: data= "page.title,page.author,page.tags,page.myCustomData" üîπ Configurazione Sito Dalla chiron.config.yaml : project: name: My Site url: https: //mysite.com author: Site Author customGlobals: contactEmail: hello@mysite.com socialLinks: twitter: @mysite github: mysite Accesso nel shortcode: data= "config.project.name,config.customGlobals.contactEmail" üîπ Dati da Plugin I plugin possono iniettare dati nel context tramite hook page:before-render : // In un plugin hooks: { 'page:before-render' : async (pageContext, context) => { // Aggiungi dati custom al page context pageContext.page.relatedPosts = [ { title: 'Post 1' , url: '/post-1' }, { title: 'Post 2' , url: '/post-2' } ]; return pageContext; } } Poi accessibili con: data= "page.relatedPosts" ‚ö° Performance Confronto con Fetch Tradizionale Aspetto Traditional Fetch Data Island HTTP Requests 1+ per widget 0 Time to Interactive 200-500

Add to chiron.config.yaml : security: allowed_cdn_domains: - my-cdn.com Mermaid Diagrams Mermaid enables you to create diagrams and visualizations using simple text syntax. Here's how you would create a chart: <canvas id= "myChart" width= "400" height= "200" ></canvas> <script> document. addEventListener ( 'DOMContentLoaded' , () => { const ctx = document. getElementById ( 'myChart' ). getContext ( '2d' ); new Chart (ctx, { type: 'bar' , data: { labels: [ 'Red' , 'Blue' , 'Yellow' , 'Green' , 'Purple' , 'Orange' ], datasets: [{ label: '# of Votes' , data: [ 12 , 19 , 3 , 5 , 2 , 3 ], backgroundColor: [ 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 0.2)' , 'rgba(54, 162, 235, 0.2)' , 'rgba(255, 206, 86, 0.2)' , 'rgba(75, 192, 192, 0.2)' , 'rgba(153, 102, 255, 0.2)' , 'rgba(255, 159, 64, 0.2)' ], borderColor: [ 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 1)' , 'rgba(54, 162, 235, 1)' , 'rgba(255, 206, 86, 1)' , 'rgba(75, 192, 192, 1)' , 'rgba(153, 102, 255, 1)' , 'rgba(255, 159, 64, 1)' ], borderWidth: 1 }] }, options: { scales: { y: { beginAtZero: true } } } }); }); </script> How It Works Frontmatter Configuration : Add external_scripts array to your page's frontmatter Named Presets : Use convenient preset names like mermaid , chartjs , d3 , etc. Custom URLs : Or specify full URLs from trusted CDNs Automatic Loading : Scripts are loaded in the correct order Opt-in : Only pages that need them load external scripts Available Presets Preset Description Use Case mermaid Diagrams and flowcharts Documentation, architecture chartjs Simple charts Data visualization d3 Advanced visualizations Complex data graphics mathjax Math notation Scientific docs, equations katex Fast math rendering Mathematical content threejs 3D graphics Interactive 3D demos prismjs Syntax highlighting Code examples Frontmatter Examples Example 1: Presets Only --- title: Diagrams Page external_scripts: - mermaid - chartjs --- Example 2: Mixed Sources --- title: Advanced Dashboard external_scripts: # Preset library - chartjs # Self-hosted (automatically allowed, no config needed) - assets/dashboard-init.js - ./js/custom-widgets.js # Custom CDN (requires chiron.config.yaml setup) - https: //my-cdn.com/analytics.js --- Example 3: Self-Hosted Only --- title: Custom Features external_scripts: - assets/my-library.js # ‚úÖ Automatically allowed - scripts/custom-init.js # ‚úÖ Automatically allowed - /js/widgets.mjs # ‚úÖ Automatically allowed --- Why self-hosted scripts are always allowed: If you're uploading a script to your site, you control it. pages.content: Chiron Documentation Overview Chiron is a modern, accessible documentation builder designed to bridge the gap between simple README files and complex documentation sites. Built with a powerful build system, it converts Markdown files into beautiful, professional documentation websites. Key Features üìù Markdown-Based : Write your documentation in simple Markdown files ‚öôÔ∏è YAML Configuration : Single configuration file for complete customization üé® Modern Design : Clean, professional interface with responsive design ‚ôø Accessibility First : WCAG 2.2 AA compliant üåô Dark Mode : Built-in theme switching üöÄ GitHub Pages Ready : Optimized for static hosting üîç SEO Optimized : Complete meta tags and structured data üì¶ Zero Runtime Dependencies : Pure HTML, CSS, and JavaScript output Quick Start Installation # Clone the repository git clone https: //github.com/agilira/chiron.git cd chiron # Install dependencies npm install # Build your documentation npm run build Basic Usage Edit chiron.config.yaml with your project details Create Markdown files in the content/ folder Run the builder : npm run build Deploy the docs/ folder to GitHub Pages Your First Page Create a new file content/my-page.md : --- title: My First Page description: This is my first documentation page --- # Welcome This is the content of my page written in **Markdown**. ## Features - Easy to write - Beautiful output - Fully customizable Add it to your navigation in chiron.config.yaml : navigation: sidebar: - section: Getting Started items: - label: My First Page file: my-page.md Run npm run build and your page is ready! Configuration The chiron.config.yaml file controls every aspect of your documentation site. Here's a minimal example: project: name: My Project title: My Project Documentation description: Documentation for my amazing project base_url: https: //username.github.io/my-project branding: company: My Company company_url: https: //mycompany.com navigation: sidebar: - section: Documentation items: - label: Home file: index.md See the full configuration file for all available options. Development Watch Mode For development, use watch mode to automatically rebuild on changes: npm run dev Preview Preview your built site locally: npm run preview Then open http://localhost:3000 in your browser. Deployment to GitHub Pages Build your site: npm run build Commit the docs/ folder to your repository In GitHub repository settings, enable GitHub Pages Set source to main branch and /docs folder Your site will be live at https://username.github.io/repository-name Features in Detail Markdown Support Chiron supports GitHub Flavored Markdown with: Headers with automatic IDs Code blocks with copy button Tables with responsive design Links with automatic external link handling Images with lazy loading Lists , blockquotes , and more Frontmatter Each Markdown file can have YAML frontmatter: --- title: Page Title description: Page description for SEO keywords: custom, page, keywords, seo author: Your Name date: 2025 - 01 - 01 --- # Content starts here Note : You can override SEO keywords per-page using the keywords field in frontmatter. pages.description: Live API explorer showing React integration with lazy loading in a static Chiron site
pages.content: Interactive API Explorer Live Demo : Test API endpoints directly in your browser with this React-powered interactive tool. This page demonstrates how Chiron enables rich interactivity only when you need it while keeping the rest of your documentation fast and lightweight. Scroll down to see the lazy loading in action! The React app below won't load until you scroll near it. What is Lazy Loading? Instead of loading 130KB of React code immediately when you open this page, Chiron uses Intersection Observer to load the app only when it enters your viewport. Benefits: ‚ö° Faster initial load - Page loads in ~50ms instead of ~200ms üì¶ Smaller payload - Only ~35KB initially (base Chiron components) üéØ Load on demand - React loads only when you scroll to it üöÄ Better UX - Users who don't scroll down don't pay the cost Try It Yourself Instructions: Open your browser's DevTools (F12) Go to the Network tab Scroll down slowly toward the demo below Watch the React scripts load dynamically! How Lazy Loading Works This interactive API explorer is a real React application that loads only when you scroll to it . 1. Intersection Observer Magic Chiron watches for when the app container enters the viewport: const observer = new IntersectionObserver ((entries) => { if (entries[ 0 ].isIntersecting) { // User scrolled to app - load it now! loadReactAndApp (); } }, { rootMargin: '200px' // Start loading 200px before visible }); 2. Simple Component Syntax In your Markdown, just use the <App> component: <App framework= "react" src= "assets/my-app.js" deps= "react,react-dom" > Custom loading placeholder... </App> 3. Dynamic Script Loading When the app enters viewport, Chiron: Shows loading spinner Loads React & ReactDOM in parallel Loads your app script Dispatches lazy-app-loaded event Your app initializes! 4. Framework Agnostic Works with any framework : React Vue Svelte Preact Vanilla JS Or anything from CDN! Performance Comparison Metric With Lazy Loading Without (old way) Initial JS ~35 KB ~165 KB Initial Load ~50ms ~200ms App Load On scroll (~150ms) On page load User doesn't scroll 0 KB overhead 130 KB wasted Key Insight : Users who never scroll to the app don't pay the React cost! Real-World Use Cases Perfect for: üîß API Documentation - Interactive testing tools üìù Form Builders - Complex configuration generators üé® Component Showcases - Live prop editing üíª Code Playgrounds - Try code in docs üìä Data Visualizations - Charts only where needed üéì Interactive Tutorials - Step-by-step guides The Code The API explorer uses React hooks: const { useState } = React; function APIExplorer () { const [endpoint, setEndpoint] = useState ( 'getUser' ); const [response, setResponse] = useState ( null ); const [loading, setLoading] = useState ( false ); const handleRequest = async () => { setLoading ( true ); const data = await fetchAPI (endpoint); setResponse (data); setLoading ( false ); }; return /* JSX */ ; } // Initialize on lazy-app-loaded event document. addEventListener ( 'lazy-app-loaded' , (e) => { if (e.detail.appId === 'react-api-root' ) { const root = ReactDOM. createRoot (e.target); root. render (React. createElement (APIExplorer)); } }); Try Different Frameworks React (This Page) <App framework= "react" src= "assets/react-app.js" deps= "react,react-dom" /> Vue <App framework= "vue" src= "assets/vue-app.js" deps= "https://unpkg.com/vue@3" /> Svelte <App framework= "svelte" src= "assets/svelte-app.js" /> The Chiron Philosophy This demo proves you can have: ‚ö° Rich interactivity where you need it üöÄ Blazing speed everywhere else üì¶ Simple integration (just a shortcode) üõ†Ô∏è No build complexity required Use what you need, where you need it. That's Chiron. See Also External Scripts Documentation - Mermaid, Chart.js, and more Custom Templates - Full page customization Performance - Why speed matters

pages.content: Data Island Pattern Demo This page demonstrates the Data Island Pattern - injecting data at build-time for lazy-loaded apps. How it Works Build Time : Chiron generates a <script type="application/json"> with page data Load Time : The app script loads only when scrolled into view (Intersection Observer) Runtime : App reads data from JSON script - zero HTTP requests ! Benefits ‚ö° Instant Data Access - No fetch() calls needed üöÄ Better Performance - Zero network latency for data üéØ SEO Friendly - Data is in the HTML source üîí Type Safe - Data structure known at build time ‚ôø Accessible - Works even if JavaScript is slow Comparison Method HTTP Requests Time to Data SEO Traditional Fetch 1+ per app 200-500ms ‚ùå Data Island 0 Instant ‚úÖ Technical Details The data attribute in the shortcode specifies which variables to inject: <App data= "page.title,config.site.name" /> Chiron generates: <script type= "application/json" id= "my-app-data" > { "title" : "Page Title" , "name" : "Site Name" } </script> The app reads it with: const data = JSON. parse ( document. getElementById ( 'my-app-data' ).textContent ); Zero runtime overhead. Maximum performance. üéØ Live Demo Scroll down to see the Intersection Observer in action! üëá What Just Happened? When you scrolled down: ‚úÖ Intersection Observer detected the container entering the viewport ‚úÖ Script loaded dynamically (check Network tab - only when visible!) ‚úÖ Event dispatched with app details ( lazy-app-loaded ) ‚úÖ App rendered without blocking initial page load Open DevTools Console to see the loading sequence! üîç

pages.title: App & Skeleton Components
pages.description: Lazy-loaded JavaScript applications with animated skeleton loaders
pages.content: App & Skeleton Components Components for loading interactive applications on-demand with elegant placeholders. App Component The <App> component enables lazy-loaded JavaScript applications using Intersection Observer. The app loads only when it enters the viewport , drastically improving performance. Basic Syntax <App id= "my-app" framework= "react" src= "assets/my-app.js" deps= "https://unpkg.com/react@18/umd/react.production.min.js" > <Skeleton lines= "3" /> </App> Attributes Attribute Type Required Description id string Yes Unique ID for the app container framework string Yes Framework type ( react , vue , svelte , vanilla ) src string Yes Path to the JavaScript app file deps string No CDN dependencies separated by comma data string No Variables to inject (Data Island pattern) Example <App id= "react-demo" framework= "react" src= "assets/react-app.js" deps= "https://unpkg.com/react@18/umd/react.production.min.js,https://unpkg.com/react-dom@18/umd/react-dom.production.min.js" > <Skeleton lines= "3" /> </App> The component works the same way for all frameworks (React, Vue, Svelte, Vanilla JS) - just change the framework attribute and bundle path. See React Demo for a complete working example Data Island Pattern Inject data from build context directly into the app (zero HTTP requests): <App id= "data-demo" framework= "vanilla" src= "assets/app.js" data= "page.title,page.description,config.site.name" > <Skeleton /> </App> The app can read the data like this: document. addEventListener ( 'lazy-app-loaded' , (e) => { if (e.detail.appId === 'data-demo' ) { const data = e.detail.data; // { title: "...", description: "...", name: "..." } // Use data without fetch! } }); Events The app emits a lazy-app-loaded event when loaded: document. addEventListener ( 'lazy-app-loaded' , (event) => { console. log ( 'App loaded:' , event.detail); // event.detail = { // appId: 'my-app', // framework: 'react', // container: HTMLElement, // data: Object, // visible: boolean, // loadTime: number (ms) // } }); Performance Benefits Metric Without Lazy Loading With Lazy Loading Initial JS ~165 KB ~35 KB Initial Load ~200ms ~50ms App Load On page load On scroll (~150ms) If user doesn't scroll 130 KB wasted 0 KB overhead Skeleton Component The <Skeleton> component displays an animated placeholder during app loading. Basic Syntax <Skeleton lines= "3" /> Parameters Attribute Type Default Description lines number 2 Number of lines to display Visual Demo 2 lines (default) - <Skeleton /> or <Skeleton lines="2" /> 3 lines - <Skeleton lines="3" /> 5 lines - <Skeleton lines="5" /> - For slideshows or taller content 8 lines - <Skeleton lines="8" /> - For very tall content Behavior All lines have 100% width except the last one which is 75% Each line height: 40px Smooth shimmer animation (1.5s loop) Automatic dark mode support Respects prefers-reduced-motion Style The component generates this HTML: <div class = "skeleton-loader" role= "status" aria-label= "Loading" > <div class = "skeleton-line skeleton-line--full" ></div> <div class = "skeleton-line skeleton-line--full" ></div> <div class = "skeleton-line skeleton-line--short" ></div> </div> Complete Example <App id= "interactive-demo" framework= "react" src= "assets/demo.js" deps= "https://unpkg.com/react@18/umd/react.production.min.js,https://unpkg.com/react-dom@18/umd/react-dom.production.min.js" data= "page.title,page.description" > <Skeleton lines= "4" /> </App> What happens: ‚úÖ Page loads fast (~50ms) ‚úÖ Skeleton visible in placeholder ‚úÖ User scrolls to the app ‚úÖ Intersection Observer detects the app ‚úÖ Loads React + ReactDOM in parallel ‚úÖ Loads the app script ‚úÖ Injects data from data attribute ‚úÖ Emits lazy-app-loaded event ‚úÖ App initializes with data ‚úÖ Skeleton fades out Best Practices ‚úÖ DO Use <Skeleton> as placeholder for better UX Set a unique id for each app Specify the correct framework Use Data Island for static data (zero latency) Load dependencies from CDN for better caching ‚ùå DON'T Don't use the same id for multiple apps Don't load heavy apps at the top of the page (defeats lazy loading) Don't forget framework dependencies Don't use data for frequently changing data (use fetch instead) Troubleshooting App doesn't load Verify the id is unique Check the console for network errors Verify dependencies are in the correct order Skeleton doesn't appear Verify it's inside the <App> ta

pages.content: FormField Component The FormField component wraps form inputs ( <input> , <textarea> , <select> ) with proper labels, helper text, error messages, and ARIA attributes automatically. Why Use FormField? Without FormField (verbose, error-prone): <div class = "form-field" > <label for = "email-123" >Email Address</label> <input type= "email" id= "email-123" name= "email" aria-describedby= "email-123-helper" required /> <span class = "form-helper-text" id= "email-123-helper" >We'll never share your email</span> </div> With FormField (clean, simple): <FormField label= "Email Address" helper= "We'll never share your email" > <input type= "email" name= "email" required /> </FormField> Basic Usage Input with Label <FormField label= "Full Name" > <input type= "text" name= "fullname" placeholder= "John Doe" /> </FormField> Input with Label and Helper <FormField label= "Email" helper= "We'll never share your email" > <input type= "email" name= "email" required /> </FormField> Input without Label For cases where the label is not needed (e.g., search inputs with aria-label ): <FormField helper= "Search our documentation" > <input type= "search" placeholder= "Search..." aria-label= "Search" /> </FormField> Error State When a field has an error, use the error attribute. It automatically: Adds the .has-error class to the wrapper Displays the error message Overrides any helper text <FormField label= "Email" error= "Please enter a valid email address" > <input type= "email" name= "email" value= "invalid-email" /> </FormField> Input Types Text Input Email Input Password Input Number Input URL Input Tel Input Date Input Time Input Textarea <FormField label= "Bio" helper= "Tell us about yourself (max 500 characters)" > <textarea name= "bio" rows= "5" maxlength= "500" ></textarea> </FormField> Select Basic Select Choose your country... Omit for fields that don't need a visible label. helper string No Helper text displayed below the field. Provides additional context. error string No Error message. pages.description: Animated loading placeholders for lazy-loaded content
pages.content: Skeleton Component The <Skeleton> component displays an animated placeholder during content loading. Perfect for lazy-loaded apps, images, or any asynchronous content. Features ‚úÖ Smooth Animation - Elegant shimmer effect ‚úÖ Customizable Lines - From 1 to unlimited lines ‚úÖ Smart Design - Last line always shorter (75% width) ‚úÖ Accessible - Full ARIA support for screen readers ‚úÖ Dark Mode - Automatic theme adaptation ‚úÖ Performance - Respects prefers-reduced-motion ‚úÖ Zero Config - Works out of the box Basic Usage <Skeleton /> Default: 2 lines (1 full-width + 1 short) Syntax <Skeleton /> // Default: 2 lines <Skeleton lines= "3" /> // 3 lines <Skeleton lines= "5" /> // 5 lines <Skeleton lines= "8" /> // 8 lines Props Prop Type Required Default Description lines number No 2 Number of skeleton lines to display Examples Default (2 lines) <Skeleton /> 3 Lines <Skeleton lines= "3" /> 5 Lines <Skeleton lines= "5" /> 8 Lines <Skeleton lines= "8" /> Perfect for tall content like slideshows or data tables. Design Pattern The skeleton follows a smart design pattern: All lines have 100% width Except the last one which is 75% width (looks more natural) Each line has 40px height (standard row height) Smooth shimmer animation (1.5s loop) Why the last line is shorter? This mimics natural content where the last line of text is often incomplete. It creates a more realistic loading state. ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà ‚Üê 100% width ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà ‚Üê 100% width ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà ‚Üê 75% width (last line) Use Cases 1. Lazy-Loaded Apps Show skeleton while the JavaScript app loads: <App id= "my-app" framework= "react" src= "/assets/app.js" > <Skeleton lines= "4" /> </App> The skeleton displays immediately, then fades out when the app is ready. 2. Loading States Indicate content is being fetched: <div class = "content-area" > {loading ? <Skeleton lines= "3" /> : <ActualContent />} </div> 3. Placeholder UI Create skeleton screens for better perceived performance: <article> <Skeleton lines= "1" /> <!-- Title --> <Skeleton lines= "5" /> <!-- Content --> <Skeleton lines= "2" /> <!-- Metadata --> </article> Accessibility The component includes proper ARIA attributes for assistive technologies: <div class = "skeleton-loader" role= "status" aria-label= "Loading" > <!-- skeleton lines --> </div> Screen Reader Behavior Screen readers announce "Loading" status No disruptive updates during animation Proper role attribute for loading indication Semantic HTML structure Keyboard Navigation Not focusable (presentational component) Does not trap focus Does not interfere with page navigation Motion Preferences The shimmer animation respects user preferences: @ media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) { .skeleton-loader { animation: none; } } Users who prefer reduced motion see a static placeholder instead of the animated shimmer. Built with a powerful build system, it converts Markdown files into beautiful, professional documentation websites. Key Features üìù Markdown-Based : Write your documentation in simple Markdown files ‚öôÔ∏è YAML Configuration : Single configuration file for complete customization üé® Modern Design : Clean, professional interface with responsive design ‚ôø Accessibility First : WCAG 2.2 AA compliant üåô Dark Mode : Built-in theme switching üöÄ GitHub Pages Ready : Optimized for static hosting üîç SEO Optimized : Complete meta tags and structured data üì¶ Zero Runtime Dependencies : Pure HTML, CSS, and JavaScript output Quick Start Installation # Clone the repository git clone https: //github.com/agilira/chiron.git cd chiron # Install dependencies npm install # Build your documentation npm run build Basic Usage Edit chiron.config.yaml with your project details Create Markdown files in the content/ folder Run the builder : npm run build Deploy the docs/ folder to GitHub Pages Your First Page Create a new file content/my-page.md : --- title: My First Page description: This is my first documentation page --- # Welcome This is the content of my page written in **Markdown**. ## Features - Easy to write - Beautiful output - Fully customizable Add it to your navigation in chiron.config.yaml : navigation: sidebar: - section: Getting Started items: - label: My First Page file: my-page.md Run npm run build and your page is ready! Configuration The chiron.config.yaml file controls every aspect of your documentation site. Here's a minimal example: project: name: My Project title: My Project Documentation description: Documentation for my amazing project base_url: https: //username.github.io/my-project branding: company: My Company company_url: https: //mycompany.com navigation: sidebar: - section: Documentation items: - label: Home file: index.md See the full configuration file for all available options. Development Watch Mode For development, use watch mode to automatically rebuild on changes: npm run dev Preview Preview your built site locally: npm run preview Then open http://localhost:3000 in your browser. Deployment to GitHub Pages Build your site: npm run build Commit the docs/ folder to your repository In GitHub repository settings, enable GitHub Pages Set source to main branch and /docs folder Your site will be live at https://username.github.io/repository-name Features in Detail Markdown Support Chiron supports GitHub Flavored Markdown with: Headers with automatic IDs Code blocks with copy button Tables with responsive design Links with automatic external link handling Images with lazy loading Lists , blockquotes , and more Frontmatter Each Markdown file can have YAML frontmatter: --- title: Page Title description: Page description for SEO keywords: custom, page, keywords, seo author: Your Name date: 2025 - 01 - 01 --- # Content starts here Note : You can override SEO keywords per-page using the keywords field in frontmatter. If not specified, global keywords from chiron.config.yaml will be used. pages.content: Privacy Policy Last Updated : January 2025 Introduction This privacy policy describes how Chiron ("we", "our", or "us") handles information when you use our documentation template. Information We Collect Chiron is a static site generator that creates documentation websites. The generated sites are static HTML files that do not collect or transmit personal information by default. Generated Websites Websites generated by Chiron: Do not collect personal data by default Do not use tracking scripts unless you explicitly add them Do not store cookies unless you enable cookie consent features Are fully under your control - you decide what to include Optional Features If you enable certain features in your configuration: Cookie Consent Banner : Allows users to manage cookie preferences Analytics Integration : Only if you manually add analytics scripts External Links : May navigate users to third-party sites with their own privacy policies Data Storage Chiron itself: Runs locally on your machine Does not send data to external servers Does not collect usage statistics Does not require registration or authentication Third-Party Services The default Chiron template may include: Google Fonts Used for typography Subject to Google's Privacy Policy Can be replaced with self-hosted fonts CDN Resources Prism.js for syntax highlighting (via CDN) Can be replaced with self-hosted versions Your Responsibilities When using Chiron to create documentation sites, you are responsible for: Compliance : Ensuring your site complies with applicable privacy laws (GDPR, CCPA, etc.) Disclosure : Informing users about any data collection or cookies Consent : Obtaining necessary consents for cookies or tracking Third-party Services : Understanding privacy implications of any services you integrate Cookies The default Chiron template includes: Essential Cookies : For theme preference (dark/light mode) Cookie Consent : Optional banner to manage user preferences You can disable all cookies by setting features.cookie_consent: false in your configuration. Children's Privacy Chiron is a developer tool and is not directed at children under 13. We do not knowingly collect information from children. Security Chiron-generated sites are static HTML files, which provides inherent security benefits: No server-side processing No database vulnerabilities No user authentication to compromise Reduced attack surface However, ensure: Your hosting provider is secure HTTPS is enabled Dependencies are kept updated Data Retention Chiron does not retain any data. Generated sites are static files under your control. International Transfers Chiron is open-source software that can be used anywhere. Generated sites can be hosted in any jurisdiction you choose. pages.description: Live API explorer showing React integration with lazy loading in a static Chiron site
pages.content: Interactive API Explorer Live Demo : Test API endpoints directly in your browser with this React-powered interactive tool. This page demonstrates how Chiron enables rich interactivity only when you need it while keeping the rest of your documentation fast and lightweight. Scroll down to see the lazy loading in action! The React app below won't load until you scroll near it. What is Lazy Loading? Instead of loading 130KB of React code immediately when you open this page, Chiron uses Intersection Observer to load the app only when it enters your viewport. Benefits: ‚ö° Faster initial load - Page loads in ~50ms instead of ~200ms üì¶ Smaller payload - Only ~35KB initially (base Chiron components) üéØ Load on demand - React loads only when you scroll to it üöÄ Better UX - Users who don't scroll down don't pay the cost Try It Yourself Instructions: Open your browser's DevTools (F12) Go to the Network tab Scroll down slowly toward the demo below Watch the React scripts load dynamically! How Lazy Loading Works This interactive API explorer is a real React application that loads only when you scroll to it . 1. Intersection Observer Magic Chiron watches for when the app container enters the viewport: const observer = new IntersectionObserver ((entries) => { if (entries[ 0 ].isIntersecting) { // User scrolled to app - load it now! loadReactAndApp (); } }, { rootMargin: '200px' // Start loading 200px before visible }); 2. Simple Component Syntax In your Markdown, just use the <App> component: <App framework= "react" src= "assets/my-app.js" deps= "react,react-dom" > Custom loading placeholder... </App> 3. Dynamic Script Loading When the app enters viewport, Chiron: Shows loading spinner Loads React & ReactDOM in parallel Loads your app script Dispatches lazy-app-loaded event Your app initializes! 4. Framework Agnostic Works with any framework : React Vue Svelte Preact Vanilla JS Or anything from CDN! Performance Comparison Metric With Lazy Loading Without (old way) Initial JS ~35 KB ~165 KB Initial Load ~50ms ~200ms App Load On scroll (~150ms) On page load User doesn't scroll 0 KB overhead 130 KB wasted Key Insight : Users who never scroll to the app don't pay the React cost! Real-World Use Cases Perfect for: üîß API Documentation - Interactive testing tools üìù Form Builders - Complex configuration generators üé® Component Showcases - Live prop editing üíª Code Playgrounds - Try code in docs üìä Data Visualizations - Charts only where needed üéì Interactive Tutorials - Step-by-step guides The Code The API explorer uses React hooks: const { useState } = React; function APIExplorer () { const [endpoint, setEndpoint] = useState ( 'getUser' ); const [response, setResponse] = useState ( null ); const [loading, setLoading] = useState ( false ); const handleRequest = async () => { setLoading ( true ); const data = await fetchAPI (endpoint); setResponse (data); setLoading ( false ); }; return /* JSX */ ; } // Initialize on lazy-app-loaded event document. addEventListener ( 'lazy-app-loaded' , (e) => { if (e.detail.appId === 'react-api-root' ) { const root = ReactDOM. createRoot (e.target); root. render (React. createElement (APIExplorer)); } }); Try Different Frameworks React (This Page) <App framework= "react" src= "assets/react-app.js" deps= "react,react-dom" /> Vue <App framework= "vue" src= "assets/vue-app.js" deps= "https://unpkg.com/vue@3" /> Svelte <App framework= "svelte" src= "assets/svelte-app.js" /> The Chiron Philosophy This demo proves you can have: ‚ö° Rich interactivity where you need it üöÄ Blazing speed everywhere else üì¶ Simple integration (just a shortcode) üõ†Ô∏è No build complexity required Use what you need, where you need it. That's Chiron. See Also External Scripts Documentation - Mermaid, Chart.js, and more Custom Templates - Full page customization Performance - Why speed matters

Println ( "Hello, World!" ) } func greet (name string) string { return fmt. Sprintf ( "Hello, %s!" , name) } ::tab{title="Rust"} // Hello World in Rust fn main () { println!( "Hello, World!" ); } fn greet (name: &str) -> String { format!( "Hello, {}!" , name) } ::: Installation Instructions You can use tabs for multi-step installation guides: :::tabs ::tab{title="npm"} # Install via npm npm install chiron --save-dev # Run the build npm run build ::tab{title="yarn"} # Install via yarn yarn add chiron --dev # Run the build yarn build ::tab{title="pnpm"} # Install via pnpm pnpm add -D chiron # Run the build pnpm build ::: Configuration Examples Show different configuration formats: :::tabs ::tab{title="YAML"} # chiron.config.yaml project: name: My Documentation base_url: https: //example.com build: output_dir: docs clean_output: true theme: primary_color: '#007bff' ::tab{title="JSON"} { "project" : { "name" : "My Documentation" , "base_url" : "https://example.com" }, "build" : { "output_dir" : "docs" , "clean_output" : true }, "theme" : { "primary_color" : "#007bff" } } ::tab{title="JavaScript"} // chiron.config.js module.exports = { project: { name: 'My Documentation' , base_url: 'https://example.com' }, build: { output_dir: 'docs' , clean_output: true }, theme: { primary_color: '#007bff' } }; ::: Platform-Specific Commands Tabs work great for platform-specific instructions: :::tabs ::tab{title="Windows"} # Windows PowerShell $env:NODE_ENV= "production" npm run build # Check if build succeeded if ($LASTEXITCODE -eq 0 ) { Write-Host "Build successful!" -ForegroundColor Green } ::tab{title="macOS"} # macOS / Linux Bash export NODE_ENV=production npm run build # Check if build succeeded if [ $? pages.title: Auth Plugin - API Reference
pages.description: Complete API reference for the Authentication Plugin
pages.content: Authentication Plugin - API Reference Complete API documentation for the Authentication Plugin. Core Methods `auth.configure(options)` Configure the authentication plugin with your settings. Parameters: options (Object) - Configuration options provider (String) - Authentication provider ('oauth', 'saml', 'custom') clientId (String) - OAuth client ID clientSecret (String) - OAuth client secret callbackUrl (String) - Callback URL after authentication Returns: void Example: auth. configure ({ provider: 'oauth' , clientId: 'abc123' , clientSecret: 'secret456' , callbackUrl: 'https://myapp.com/callback' }); `auth.login(credentials)` Authenticate a user with credentials. Parameters: credentials (Object) - User credentials username (String) - Username or email password (String) - User password Returns: Promise<User> - Authenticated user object Example: const user = await auth. login ({ username: 'user@example.com' , password: 'securepassword' }); `auth.logout()` Log out the current user and clear session. Returns: Promise<void> Example: await auth. logout (); Session Management `auth.getSession()` Get the current session information. Returns: Session | null - Current session or null if not authenticated `auth.refreshSession()` Refresh the current session token. Returns: Promise<Session> - Updated session Events The plugin emits the following events: login - Fired when user logs in successfully logout - Fired when user logs out session:refresh - Fired when session is refreshed error - Fired on authentication errors Example: auth. on ( 'login' , (user) => { console. log ( 'User logged in:' , user.email); }); Error Handling All methods throw specific error types: AuthenticationError - Invalid credentials ConfigurationError - Invalid configuration SessionError - Session-related errors Example: try { await auth. login (credentials); } catch (error) { if (error instanceof auth.AuthenticationError) { console. error ( 'Invalid credentials' ); } }

pages.title: Auth Plugin - Configuration Guide
pages.description: Step-by-step guide to configure the Authentication Plugin
pages.content: Authentication Plugin - Configuration Guide This guide will walk you through setting up and configuring the Authentication Plugin. Installation Install the plugin via npm: npm install @mylib/plugin-auth Basic Configuration Step 1: Initialize the Plugin const auth = require ( '@mylib/plugin-auth' ); auth. configure ({ provider: 'oauth' , clientId: process.env.OAUTH_CLIENT_ID, clientSecret: process.env.OAUTH_CLIENT_SECRET, callbackUrl: 'https://yourapp.com/auth/callback' }); Step 2: Set Up Routes app. get ( '/login' , (req, res) => { const loginUrl = auth. getLoginUrl (); res. redirect (loginUrl); }); app. get ( '/auth/callback' , async (req, res) => { try { const user = await auth. handleCallback (req.query.code); req.session.user = user; res. redirect ( '/dashboard' ); } catch (error) { res. redirect ( '/login?error=auth_failed' ); } }); Advanced Configuration Custom Authentication Provider You can implement a custom authentication provider: auth. configure ({ provider: 'custom' , authenticate: async (credentials) => { // Your custom authentication logic const user = await yourAuthService. verify (credentials); return user; } }); Session Configuration Configure session behavior: auth. configure ({ session: { duration: 3600 , // 1 hour in seconds autoRefresh: true , refreshThreshold: 300 // Refresh 5 minutes before expiry } }); Role-Based Access Control Set up RBAC: auth. configure ({ rbac: { roles: [ 'admin' , 'user' , 'guest' ], permissions: { admin: [ 'read' , 'write' , 'delete' ], user: [ 'read' , 'write' ], guest: [ 'read' ] } } }); // Check permissions if (auth. hasPermission (user, 'write' )) { // Allow write operation } Environment Variables Recommended environment variables: # OAuth Configuration OAUTH_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id OAUTH_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret OAUTH_CALLBACK_URL=https: //yourapp.com/auth/callback # Session Configuration SESSION_SECRET=your_session_secret SESSION_DURATION= 3600 Security Best Practices Always use HTTPS in production Store secrets in environment variables , never in code Implement rate limiting on authentication endpoints Enable 2FA for sensitive applications Regularly rotate secrets and tokens Troubleshooting Common Issues Issue: "Invalid callback URL" Ensure your callback URL matches exactly what's configured in your OAuth provider Check for trailing slashes Issue: "Session expired too quickly" Increase session.duration in configuration Enable autoRefresh for long-running sessions Issue: "Authentication fails silently" Check error event listeners Enable debug logging: auth.setLogLevel('debug') Next Steps Read the API Reference for detailed method documentation Check out example implementations Join our community forum for support

pages.title: Cache Plugin - API Reference
pages.description: Complete API reference for the Cache Plugin
pages.content: Cache Plugin - API Reference Complete API documentation for the Cache Plugin. Configuration `cache.configure(options)` Configure the cache plugin. Parameters: options (Object) - Configuration options backend (String) - Backend type ('redis', 'memcached', 'memory', 'file') host (String) - Backend host (for Redis/Memcached) port (Number) - Backend port defaultTTL (Number) - Default time-to-live in seconds (default: 3600) compression (Boolean) - Enable compression (default: false) Example: cache. configure ({ backend: 'redis' , host: 'localhost' , port: 6379 , defaultTTL: 3600 , compression: true }); Core Methods `cache.set(key, value, options)` Store a value in the cache. Parameters: key (String) - Cache key value (Any) - Value to store (will be serialized) options (Object, optional) - Options ttl (Number) - Time-to-live in seconds compress (Boolean) - Override compression setting Returns: Promise<boolean> - Success status Example: await cache. set ( 'user:123' , { name: 'John' , email: 'john@example.com' }, { ttl: 1800 }); `cache.get(key)` Retrieve a value from the cache. Parameters: key (String) - Cache key Returns: Promise<Any | null> - Cached value or null if not found Example: const user = await cache. get ( 'user:123' ); if (user) { console. log ( 'Cache hit:' , user.name); } `cache.delete(key)` Delete a value from the cache. Parameters: key (String) - Cache key Returns: Promise<boolean> - Success status Example: await cache. delete ( 'user:123' ); `cache.clear(pattern)` Clear multiple keys matching a pattern. Parameters: pattern (String, optional) - Key pattern (supports wildcards: * ) Returns: Promise<number> - Number of keys deleted Example: // Clear all user keys await cache. clear ( 'user:*' ); // Clear entire cache await cache. clear (); Batch Operations `cache.mget(keys)` Get multiple values at once. Parameters: keys (Array ) - Array of cache keys Returns: Promise<Array<Any | null>> - Array of values (null for missing keys) Example: const [user1, user2] = await cache. mget ([ 'user:123' , 'user:456' ]); `cache.mset(entries, options)` Set multiple values at once. Parameters: entries (Object) - Key-value pairs options (Object, optional) - Options (same as set() ) Returns: Promise<boolean> - Success status Example: await cache. mset ({ 'user:123' : userData1, 'user:456' : userData2 }, { ttl: 3600 }); Cache Statistics `cache.stats()` Get cache statistics. Returns: Promise<Object> - Statistics object hits (Number) - Cache hits misses (Number) - Cache misses keys (Number) - Total keys memory (Number) - Memory usage in bytes Example: const stats = await cache. stats (); console. log ( `Hit rate: ${(stats.hits / (stats.hits + stats.misses) * 100).toFixed(2)}%` ); Events hit - Cache hit occurred miss - Cache miss occurred set - Value was set delete - Value was deleted error - Error occurred Example: cache. on ( 'miss' , (key) => { console. log ( 'Cache miss for key:' , key); });
